content: Great article — thanks. Many years ago I listed out the skills I had with a one to ten range and years of experience. I also included areas that I had exposure to — and some of those would be in the order of 2 or 3 out of 10 (and I think 9 was the highest I gave myself). It was marked at the time (in a technical IT field) that the skills matrix was useful — it help recruiters sort through skills that were not well understood by the hiring manager or the agency. With children 17 and 20 years old, I am glad that they have had decent work experience; my 17 year old daughter is working three jobs whilst doing year 12 and my 20 year old son has joined the army as an Electrical Technician — so his future is sorted until he gets past the early 20’s that are most fraught with underemployment.
